column4: how can i secure my ubuntu installation enough so that it's to log in from the outside
i'm trying to set up a secure and easy ssh connection to my ubuntu machine from the outside world
i'm trying to make sure it's secure, i heard about people using special encryption keys they store on a thumb drive
or how to configure to use secure passphrases etc
you want to go read about authorized_keys or just use a very good password
right now i'm using ssh to log into my new ubuntu machine on my own subnet, behind my router, but i want to secure it so i can log in from work, or maybe even have the ubuntu box on a dmz
what about stuff like intrusion detection, like does a basic ubuntu box do anything special if it thinks that someone is trying to brute force their way in?

if you port forward only port 22 to your linux box, make sure root is not allowed ssh access and set a good password on your account you should be ok. Of course keeping up with security updates is a must
do i need to look into snort or is that overkill?
if i can wrap my head around securing ubuntu behind myfirewall, i eventually want ubuntu to -be- my firewall
or some other linux based firewall
In my opinion that would be overkill if all you were doing was ssh
well it's a start. i'm learning.
ssh i figure is a good place to start beause you can tunnel a lot of things through ssh
